channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russian Airstrikes Kill at Least 35 at Base Near Polish Border
item.description: More than 100 were injured after missiles hit a base used to train foreign fighters. An American journalist was killed while reporting in a Kyiv suburb that has come under heavy shelling.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: U.K. vs. Oligarchs: ‘The Gloves Are Now Off’
item.description: Russia’s war in Ukraine has finally led the British government to go after ultrawealthy Russians in London. But curbing the flood of corrupt money will require going after more than the big names.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of London. Some Britons are calling on their government to curb a phenomenon that some call the “London laundromat.”

item.title: Missiles Fired From Iran Hit Near U.S. Consulate Site in Iraq
item.description: No serious injuries were reported from the strike, outside the city of Erbil in the Kurdish region of Iraq, and an American official said the consulate site was undamaged.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
item.media:description: A building on Sunday in Erbil, Iraq, that was damaged by missiles.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Executes 81 People
item.description: It was the kingdom’s largest mass execution in years. In many cases, the charges involved “not a drop of blood,” a rights activist said.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Rights groups said the executions announced Saturday flew in the face of claims by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman that Saudi Arabia was overhauling its justice system.

item.title: Pandemic Fears Give Way to a Rush for Bomb Shelters
item.description: Since Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, European anxiety has shifted from Covid to nuclear annihilation. Bunkers, survival guides and iodine pills are flying off the shelves.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giulio Cavicchioli, the owner of Minus Energie in Italy, has gone from working on 50 bunkers in the past 22 years to fielding 500 inquiries in the past two weeks.

item.title: Covid Surge in New Caledonia, in the Pacific, HIts Indigenous Hardest
item.description: New Caledonia escaped the coronavirus for a year and a half, but a surge in cases has led to a state of emergency, with the disease disproportionately hurting the French territory’s Indigenous people.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: “None of us expected Covid to come here,” said Marie-Janne Issamatro, center, with her family in Nouméa, the capital of New Caledonia.

item.title: India Accidentally Fires a Missile at Pakistan. Calm Ensues.
item.description: Mistrust runs deep between the nuclear-armed neighbors, but Pakistan had a low-key response to what India called a “technical malfunction.” No casualties were reported.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Missiles on display last year during India’s Republic Day parade in New Delhi.

item.title: Russian Invasion Could Spur Covid Surge in Ukraine, Doctors Say
item.description: War has pushed Covid out of people’s minds while forcing them into crowded and unsanitary conditions that are fertile ground for the coronavirus, polio and other pathogens.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral for three Ukrainian soldiers on Friday in Lviv. Since the start of the war, for most Ukrainians the threat from Russia has far overshadowed that of the virus.

item.title: France’s Green Party Fails to Connect Ahead of Election
item.description: As a presidential election looms, the Greens lag far behind in the polls. Analysts say the party has failed to inspire voters and show them it can rule.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yannick Jadot, the presidential candidate for the Green Party of France, at a rally in Montpellier last month.

item.title: How a Line of Russian Tanks Became an Inviting Target for Ukrainians
item.description: A skirmish in an eastern suburb of Kyiv illustrated how close Russian forces have come as they continued to tighten a noose on the city, but also revealed their strategic vulnerabilities.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Destroyed Russian tanks are seen on a main road after battles near Brovary, north of Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Europe’s Trains Take Fighters to Ukraine, and Bring Back Refugees
item.description: Built up over 150 years of conflicts that defined modern-day Europe, railways have played a central role in the continent’s peacetime integration. Now they’re back on a war footing.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vitali Slobodianiuk, right, and Volodymyr Kotsyuba, both Ukrainians, on a train from Prague to Przemysl in Poland. They were going back to Ukraine to join the fight against Russia’s invading army.

item.title: Russian Demands to Ease Sanctions Halt Nuclear Talks With Iran
item.description: Russia has injected its fight against sanctions into talks aimed at restoring a nuclear agreement with Iran. The Russian demands have delayed the prospect of a deal.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran in 2010. Tehran, which wants the removal of economic sanctions the United States has imposed on it, has criticized the new Russian demands.

item.title: ‘Hurricane Hazel’ Is Still a Force at 101, and After 36 Years as Mayor
item.description: After playing pro hockey in the 1940s, Hazel McCallion entered politics at a time when few women held high office, leading a major Canadian city through epic growth. Her endorsements still matter.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hazel McCallion at her home in Mississauga, Ontario.

item.title: China Has Tools to Help Russia’s Economy. None Are Big Enough to Save It.
item.description: Any financial lifeline that Beijing can offer Moscow involves taking on risk and won’t have the power to reverse the damage of sanctions imposed by the United States and its allies.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, the leader of China, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Deadly Airstrikes in Ukraine’s West
item.description: Plus Omicron’s impact in the South Pacific and the struggles of the French Greens.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Former President Obama Says He Has Coronavirus
item.description: He tweeted that he has a scratchy throat but is otherwise fine.
item.dc:creator: Traci Carl
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama speaking at a campaign drive-in rally for Joe Biden in 2020.

item.title: Russia Asked China for Military and Economic Aid for Ukraine War, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Jake Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, plans to meet with a top Chinese official on Monday in Rome to discuss the war and China’s role.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin reviewed a military honor guard with President Xi Jinping at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing in 2018.

item.title: ‘Things Will Only Get Worse.’ Putin’s War Sends Russians Into Exile.
item.description: Thousands of Russians saw their comfortable, middle-class lives fade overnight with the invasion ordered by President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians who fled after Russia invaded Ukraine gathered Saturday at a volunteer’s apartment in Istanbul to share their stories and get tips on settling in Turkey.

item.title: Ukrainian Refugees Find Shelter and a Hearty Welcome For Their Pets in Romania
item.description: Viktor and Rachel Borovic had only two hours to prepare to flee their city. But they were clear about what was important to them.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktor and Rachel Borovic traveled from Sumy, Ukraine, with their dog, Busia, and their cat, Coco, to a makeshift shelter in the Mandachi Hotel and Spa in Suceava, Romania.

item.title: Power Supply Restored at Nuclear Plant in Chernobyl, Ukraine Says
item.description: Russian troops have occupied the nuclear power plant since late February.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: A monument in front of the giant protective dome built over the sarcophagus of the destroyed fourth reactor of Chernobyl nuclear power plant, as seen in a photograph from 2020.

item.title: Filmmaker Brent Renaud Spent His Career Capturing the Human Toll of War
item.description: Mr. Renaud’s final assignment was documenting refugees fleeing across bridges in Irpin, Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat

item.title: Afghan Aviators Hide as Taliban Urge Them to Return to Duty
item.description: Many former Afghan Air Force members fear they could be killed by the Taliban if they came out of hiding, but others have joined the nascent Taliban air force.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former member of an elite divison of the Afghan Air Force who refused to join the Taliban’s force is now in hiding in Kabul.

item.title: Unvaccinated M.L.B. Players Will Not Be Allowed to Play in Canada
item.description: Canada’s border restrictions bar those players, and the players will not be paid while the team is abroad as part of the sport’s new labor agreement.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: At Rogers Centre in Toronto in September.

item.title: Red Cross Warns Time Is Running Out For Civilians in Mariupol
item.description: Russian forces encircled the city nearly two weeks ago, and as the death toll rises, eyewitnesses have reported there is little food or clean water, and no medicine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier guards his position on Saturday in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: 300,000 in Hong Kong Isolate at Home as COVID Cases Rise
item.description: The city’s officials are scrambling to build quarantine and mass quarantine centers as cases of the Omicron and Delta variants spread widely.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Health care workers delivering items to patients at a makeshift Covid-19 isolation facility in Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: Brent Renaud, an American Journalist, Is Killed in Ukraine
item.description: An award-winning filmmaker and journalist, Mr. Renaud, 50, was killed while reporting in a suburb of Kyiv. Another journalist was wounded.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Brent Renaud, right, and his brother Craig in Little Rock, Ark., in 2007.

item.title: Russian Invasion of Ukraine Awakens Europe
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has unexpectedly transformed Europe.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Demonstrators hold a giant European Union flag at an anti-war rally in Prague.

item.title: The Base Attacked In Western Ukraine Has Been a Hub For Foreign Militaries
item.description: The base outside Lviv that was attacked by Russian forces early on Sunday was a key link between Ukraine’s armed forces and Western militaries before the war.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers and American National Guard soldiers last month during a training in the use of American-provided M141 bunker defeat munitions at the International Peacekeeping and Security Center near Yavoriv, Ukraine.

item.title: South Korea exceeds 380,000 new cases in a day shortly after its presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign rally last week for Yoon Suk-yeol, the presidential candidate who was eventually declared the winner, in Paju, South Korea.

item.title: Oregon and Washington State, known for cautious Covid strategies, lift their statewide mask mandates.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Walters
item.media:description: Placing an order at a bakery in Yakima, Wash., in 2020.

item.title: Kidnapping of Ukrainian Mayor in Melitopol Met With a Show of Resistance
item.description: The 33-year-old mayor of Melitopol, Ivan Fyodorov, encouraged defiance. Then he was arrested, and hasn’t been heard from since.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Neil MacFarquhar

item.title: Ukrainian and Russian Soldiers Fight Street Battles Near Kyiv
item.description: The capture of the once affluent suburb of Irpin would potentially help Moscow encircle the nearby capital, military analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rose around Kyiv on Saturday, as artillery duels continued in the capital’s suburbs.

item.title: After Days of Uncertainty, a Ukrainian Soldier Is Laid to Rest
item.description: Senior Lt. Vasyl Vyshyvanyi was killed by Russian forces on March 3, but heavy combat kept the military from evacuating his body. Six days later, he was buried in his home village outside Lviv.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Natalia Yermak, Benjamin Foley, Brent McDonald and Ben Laffin
item.media:credit: Benjamin Foley for The New York Times

item.title: In a Kyiv Basement, 19 Surrogate Babies Are Trapped by War but Kept Alive by Nannies
item.description: Some surrogate mothers are trapped by the fighting as their due dates near. And newborns face uncertain fates, with many biological parents now unable to travel to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nanny caring for babies born to surrogate mothers in a nursery in Kyiv, Ukraine. Many parents of such babies are now unable to come to Ukraine because of the war.

item.title: Western Ukraine Suffers Rare Russian Attacks
item.description: Western Ukraine has been a safe haven for Ukrainian refugees, as well as businessmen, journalists and diplomats. But attacks in two cities pierced the sense of security in the region.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners stand for the national anthem during a funeral in Lutsk on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. to Send Arms to Ukraine, as Russia Intensifies Campaign of Destruction
item.description: A defiant mayor of a captured city was kidnapped by Russian troops, Ukrainian authorities say, an act that prompted hundreds to protest.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, early Saturday morning after a night of heavy Russian bombardment.

item.title: Ukraine War Ushers In ‘New Era’ for Biden and U.S. Abroad
item.description: President Biden is rethinking relationships with allies as well as rivals — including China, Iran and Venezuela — to counter President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: The aftermath of a cruise missile strike this week in Mykolaiv, Ukraine. Experts say Russia’s attack will color most U.S. foreign policy decisions for the foreseeable future.

item.title: Mask mandates were extended for U.S. transit, but dropped in many other settings: The week in Covid news.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stuyvesant High School students walking to class in Lower Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: New York City Booster Shot Data Shows Major Racial Disparities
item.description: The data showed that only about 36 percent of city residents had received a booster shot, and the numbers varied significantly by neighborhood and race.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wong
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan in December. New data show that the number of city residents who have received Covid booster shots varies significantly by neighborhood and demographic group.

item.title: Pandemic Playlists
item.description: Sad bangers and other songs that get us through.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Yousur Al-Hlou and Valerie Hopkins

item.title: Arctic Security Concerns Resurface in Canada’s Territories Amid Russian War
item.description: Between melting sea ice and increased militarization, the Arctic is changing, and premiers in Canada’s territories say the Russian war is another reason to put Arctic security on the policy forefront.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Canadian soldiers took part in the Nanook-Nunalivut exercises in 2019, meant to get troops up to Russian levels of readiness in extreme cold.

item.title: Russian Scientists Face Isolation Following Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: International collaborations are unraveling as researchers, including many in Russia, speak out against the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Alex Cretey-Systermans for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors to the Science and Innovation globe at the European Organization for Nuclear Research, or CERN, in Geneva, Switzerland, in 2018.

item.title: An Author Wrote About Her Sister’s Murder. It Led to a Breakthrough.
item.description: Cristina Rivera Garza wanted to shed light on the life of her sister, killed 30 years ago. Her book, part of a larger call for justice by women in Mexico, helped locate the suspect.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin P. Russell

item.title: Hundreds of Planes Are Stranded in Russia. They May Never Be Recovered.
item.description: Western companies that own the planes face little prospect of getting them back, meaning billions of dollars in losses.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: Aeroflot planes at Sheremetyevo Airport in Moscow last month.

item.title: That Russian Business You’re Boycotting Isn’t Actually Russian
item.description: The consumer activism that makes a vodka C.E.O. say: ‘Do you know we’re Latvian?’
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The owners of Russia House, a restaurant in Dupont Circle of Washington, D.C., have said that the business has no connection with Russia.

item.title: Ukrainian Minister Has Turned Digital Tools Into Modern Weapons of War
item.description: Mykhailo Fedorov, Ukraine’s youngest minister, has turned technology, cryptocurrency and social media into modern weapons of war.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Mykhailo Fedorov, a vice prime minister of Ukraine and former tech entrepreneur, in 2020.

item.title: China dismisses two mayors and Shanghai closes schools as an outbreak spreads further.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Lining up for coronavirus tests on Friday in Changchun, China.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth is Skipping Next Week’s Commonwealth Day Service
item.description: It is still less than a month since the British monarch tested positive for the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Gaitri Issar Kumar, the high commissioner of India, greeting Queen Elizabeth II via videolink on Tuesday. Ms. Kumar was at Buckingham Palace; the queen was in Windsor Castle.

item.title: With a lot of the world yet to be vaccinated, protesters demand that the technology be shared.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: A manufacturing lab for Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccines in Marburg, Germany. Protesters criticized Germany, among other countries, for not waiving intellectual property rules for Covid vaccines.

item.title: Slowed on the Battlefield, Russia Widens Bombardment of Ukrainian Cities
item.description: But military experts, citing previous Russian campaigns, say that strategy is unlikely to succeed without bloody urban fighting.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Eric Schmitt and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: An explosion Friday after a Russian army tank fired on an apartment building in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: American Officials Believe They Have Located Putin’s Yacht
item.description: They say they have indications that the $700 million, 459-foot yacht, which is in dry dock in Italy, is associated with the Russian president, backing an earlier claim by a former crew member.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Michael Forsythe, David D. Kirkpatrick and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: The Scheherazade dominates the waterfront in the small Italian town of Marina di Carrara where it has been moored since September.

item.title: The New Captain of the Endurance Shipwreck Is an Anemone
item.description: A who’s who of the new invertebrate crew steering Ernest Shackleton’s sunken ship in the Weddell Sea.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Falklands Maritime Heritage Trust, NOAA Exploration and Research, Alamy

item.title: Britain’s High Court rules against a virus-related ban on a memorial vigil in London last year.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: People held up smartphones in protest as the London police moved in to break up a memorial vigil for a murder victim on March 13, 2021.

item.title: Parents Relying on Ukraine Surrogates Desperately Seek Their Newborns
item.description: The Russian invasion has disrupted a thriving hub of legal commercial surrogacy. Some couples are risking trips into the war zone to get their children.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: A rescue team evacuated Lenny and Moishe, making a daylong journey from Kyiv to Rzeszow, Poland.

item.title: Russian Sieges in Ukraine Are Prompting Flashbacks for Syrians
item.description: “We feel for them and say, may God be with you,” said one Syrian who endured hunger and cold when his own government, backed by Russia, besieged Aleppo.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A man walked down a street damaged by shelling in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Saudi Blogger Raif Badawi Is Released From Prison
item.description: Amnesty International welcomed news of the release of Raif Badawi, whose case became a lightening rod for rights campaigners and reflected Saudi Arabia’s lack of tolerance for dissent.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ensaf Haidar holding a portrait of her husband, Raif Badawi, in France in 2015.

item.title: The global supply chain’s pandemic recovery is another casualty of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the Ukrainian port of Mykolaiv on the Black Sea, in February.

item.title: Kamala Harris Says U.S. Must Bear Higher Gas Prices to Punish Russia
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris, visiting NATO ally Romania, insisted that the higher costs of energy associated with sanctions imposed on Moscow over its war on Ukraine would be worth the pain.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris met with President Klaus Iohannis of Romania in Otopeni, Romania, on Friday.

item.title: How The New York Times Verifies Reporting on the Ukraine War
item.description: To cut through the fog of propaganda and misinformation on both sides, The Times has deployed dozens of journalists to Ukraine to witness events as they unfold.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier running to check on a family after a mortar shell exploded on a civilian evacuation route in Irpin, Ukraine.

item.title: How Roman Abramovich, a Russian Oligarch, Found Himself Under Sanctions
item.description: The oligarch’s billions and his Kremlin connections secured him favors and elite status in the West. Now they’ve landed him on a sanctions list.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick, Isabel Kershner, Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: On Thursday, Britain froze the assets of Roman Abramovich, the billionaire owner of the Chelsea Football Club.

item.title: Over Ukraine, Lumbering Turkish-Made Drones Are an Ominous Sign for Russia
item.description: The Bayraktar TB2 has become a rallying symbol for Ukrainians, who are singing songs about them and posting videos of their success.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Bayraktar TB2 drones are assembled in Turkey, but rely extensively on electronics made in the United States and Canada.
